topic.title: ENET Ethernet Management Interface

body.p: The ENET subsystem, the Ethernet Management port and the packet cache (Internal CPU) communicate via the Management CPB (MCPB). The figures below shows the possible management insert and extract path flows for packets to and from the CPU packet cache interface.

fig.title: Ethernet Management Paths to/from CPU PKT_CACHE
Management Paths between CPU PKT_CACHE and Ethernet Management Interface

body.p: Packets can be inserted/extrtacted for both directions: ingress and egress. Packet such as PTP, SyncE, LinkOAM, LACP and others can be inserted/extracted. All inserted/extracted packets transit through the internal CPU. As such, packets extracted from the Ethernet datapath are sent to the CPU, which can reformat them as needed for transmission on the Ethernet Management port by replacing the extract header with the external header. Similarly, packets inserted from the Ethernet Management Interface pass through the internal CPU, which reformat them as needed for proper insertion into the Ethernet datapath.

In the egress insert path of the ENET, inserted packets are dissected to remove a proprietary VLAN header carrying time-stamp control information and reflection control information. Packets are issued onto the egress path and may be time-stamped (one step) or reflected with critical timestamp information (two steps).
The MCPB is designed to have enough buffering for 3 maximum packet size of 2048 bytes per channel. Beyond that, the MCPB queues may overflow and the bandwidth may be compromised.
